mn56:29.34: with three knowledges, he has attained to holiness,
mn56:29.35: he has bathed, he knows philology,
mn56:29.36: he’s tranquil, he understands what is known;
mn56:29.37: he crushes resistance, he is the lord:
mn56:29.38: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
mn56:29.40: he has attained the goal and explains it;
mn56:29.42: neither leaning forward nor pulling back,
mn56:29.44: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
mn56:29.46: not following inner thoughts, he is pure,
mn56:29.48: secluded, he has reached the peak,
mn56:29.49: crossed over, he helps others across:
mn56:29.50: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
mn56:29.51: He’s peaceful, his wisdom is vast,
mn56:29.52: with great wisdom, he’s free of greed;
mn56:29.53: he is the Realized One, the Holy One,
mn56:29.56: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
mn56:29.57: He has cut off craving and is awakened,
mn56:29.59: a mighty spirit worthy of offerings,
mn56:29.61: grand, he has reached the peak of glory:
mn56:29.62: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.”
mn56:30.1: “But when did you compose these praises of the ascetic Gotama’s beautiful qualities, householder?”
mn56:30.2: “Sir, suppose there was a large heap of many different flowers. A deft garland-maker or their apprentice could tie them into a colorful garland.
mn56:30.3: In the same way, the Buddha has many beautiful qualities to praise, many hundreds of such qualities.
mn56:30.4: Who, sir, would not praise the praiseworthy?”
mn56:31.1: Unable to bear this honor paid to the Buddha, the Jain Ñātika spewed hot blood from his mouth there and then.
